feed.title: Comments on Validating Architecture with Visual Studio 2010
feed.subtitle: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

entry.title: By: Alex Ullrich
entry.content:
My first impression is that what’s built into VS2010 is not as advanced as NDepend. You can get pretty good dependency diagrams, and this architecture validation feature is great (I wanted to jump for joy when I saw the way it worked with Team’s “Gated Check-Ins”) but you don’t get the same fine-grained control that NDepend gives you. The lack of CQL is a big drawback form my perspective. But we use TFS at work, and the integration there could be a massive plus. I’m really going to have to dig into this more deeply in the near future.

The flipside is its’ much easier to set up this kind of validation than with NDepend – I think the new tools will be much easier to digest for people who are unfamiliar with this kind of thing. And I have little doubt that they will continue to improve.

If you want to kick the tires on the team integration without spending anyone’s money, try out the VM images Denis wrote about earlier
